adjective.description: Easy to perceive, understand, or interpret.
examples: clear and precise directions
her handwriting was clear
am I making myself clear?
the clear glass of the French windows
a stream of clear water

adjective.description: Free of any obstructions or unwanted objects.
examples: with a clear road ahead he shifted into high gear
I had a clear view in both directions
his desktop was almost clear
the truck was wedged in the ditch, one wheel clear of the ground
a clear profit of $1,100

adjective.description: Denoting a palatalized form of the sound of the letter l (as in leaf in most accents of English).

adverb.description: So as to be out of the way of or away from.
examples: he leapt clear of the car
stand clear, I'll start the plane up
he had time to get clear away

verb.description: Remove an obstruction or unwanted item or items from.
examples: the drive had been cleared of snow
Carolyn cleared the table and washed up

verb.description: Remove (an obstruction or unwanted item) from somewhere.
examples: Karen cleared the dirty plates
park staff cleared away dead trees

verb.description: Get past or over (something) safely or without touching it.
examples: the plane rose high enough to clear the trees
she cleared 1.50 metres in the high jump

verb.description: Officially show or declare (someone) to be innocent.
examples: his sport's ruling body had cleared him of cheating

verb.description: Give official approval or authorization to.
examples: I cleared him to return to his squadron
synonyms: give one's seal of approval to

verb.description: Earn or gain (an amount of money) as a net profit.
examples: I would hope to clear £50,000 profit from each match

phrases: The contenders are clearing the decks and making ready to do battle.
This is a government that is clearing the decks.
It was always spelt out to me that I would have to trim the wage bill and the playing staff and there has been quite a bit of clearing the decks.
Your Honours, may I clear the decks so far as the facts which of course are not as factual inquiry before this Court but without which we cannot win.
But it was a case of clearing the decks, then having a look at what was left, and trying to build from there.
He's had two children by her and then in 2002 he clears off.
The soldiers quickly cleared out of the room.
Traditionally weddings are short and the crowd clears out quickly afterwards.
all my health problems cleared up
origin: Middle English: from Old French cler, from Latin clarus.
